Award.AwardTitle: CCF: AF Analytical Tools for Natural Algorithms

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to build an algorithmic foundation
for the analysis of complex self-organizing systems.
Computing theory has been successful at
pinning down the computational power of
common dynamical systems, but less so
at analyzing their behavior and functionality.
Recent research points to the potential benefits
of viewing these systems as "natural algorithms."
The approach is premised on the belief that
the algorithm itself is at least as important
as the data it generates and that
the current reliance on simulations and statistics
must be supplemented with analytical tools,
something akin to an ``algorithms calculus.''
The research will be oriented along the following lines:
new proof techniques and analytical tools;
communication-based algorithmic renormalization;
geometry, topology, and approximation of complex systems.

The ambition of this project is to lay
the foundations of an algorithmic theory of
complex adaptive systems. Algorithm design
has been one of the most fruitful
areas of computer science in the past few decades.
Building a bridge between this intellectual discipline
and the ever-growing area of complex systems
could potentially have a major impact on science as a whole.
Accordingly, the present project will involve
collaborations with computer scientists, control theorists,
physicists, and systems biologists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project set out to investigate the concept of the “natural algorithm” as a modeling tool for the analysis of complex systems in the living world. The premise of this work was that the language of differential equations is not sufficienty expressive to cope with the high descriptive diversity of multiagent agent systems and so must be enriched with an algorithmic idiom. To test this proposition, the project focused its attention on “influence systems,” a large family of systems designed to model complex interactions, such as those commonly encountered in social networks, animal swarming, opinion dynamics, etc. By concentrating further on diffusive models, a class of influence systems providing a grand generalization of diffusion, the PI was able to introduce a number of new analytical tools (such as the “s-energy”) and prove some surprising results. Among the latter, the periodicity of diffusive influence systems stands out. Informally, the result explains why, somewhat paradoxically, interaction via blogs or social networks is more likely to produce consensus than via older media such as radio, tv, or newspapers. Properly tuned, the latter can even be chaotic (in the technical sense of the term) and produce all sorts of unpredictable behaviors. The result relies on a new theory of renormalization for dynamic networks.

The introduction of the "s-energy" represents a major departure from traditional approaches to the convergence of diffusive systems. Roughly, instead of measuring "progress" one step at a time (as would spectral techniques), the s-energy sets a parameter carefully, the "temperature," and produces a global measure of the system's behavior at all time scales. The s-energy can be interpreted as a partition function, a concept borrowed from statistical physics. It can be used to rederive most of the classical bounds on the mixing time of random walks in undirected graphs.
